channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Letter From Europe: British View of Europe Faces a Test
item.description: As Britain has become more Europeanized, it has also become more euroskeptic; this may benefit the United Kingdom Independence Party.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:description: One of the United Kingdom Independence Party's European election campaign posters.

item.title: Climate Change Study Finds U.S. Is Already Widely Affected
item.description: Declaring that the issue of human-induced climate change had “moved firmly into the present,” a major study found that water shortages, torrential rains, heat waves and wildfires were worsening.
item.dc:creator: By JUSTIN GILLIS
item.media:description: Cracked earth on a farm near Mendota, California, which has been swept by a punishing drought.

item.title: India Ink: Alphonso Mangoes Flood Indian Market After E.U. Ban
item.description: Lovers of the fruit, traditionally prized for its taste and scarcity, are enjoying the drop in prices, but for farmers across Maharashtra grappling with crop failure because of unseasonal rain and hailstorms, the ban comes as further bad news.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: Arvind Morde, a mango retailer and exporter, at the Crawford market in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

item.title: At Pistorius Trial, Witness Re-Enacts Screams
item.description: Two neighbors testified that they heard a high-pitched male voice screaming on the night Oscar Pistorius, the South African track star, shot and killed his girlfriend.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Another Violent Attack at Railway Station in China
item.description: An attack at a railway station in Guangzhou is the third such assault since March.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: A police officer stood guard near the scene of a knife attack at the Guangzhou Railway Station on Tuesday.

item.title: 4 Employed by Operator of Doomed South Korean Ferry Are Arrested
item.description: The officials were arrested on charges of overloading the ship with cargo, a senior prosecutor said on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Rights Lawyer Detained Ahead of Tiananmen Anniversary
item.description: Pu Zhiqiang has been formally detained on suspicion of “picking quarrels and provoking trouble” after meeting with other rights activists and scholars to discuss the 1989 crackdown.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Authorities Block Flights Into Eastern Ukraine
item.description: The closing, which was not officially explained, coincided with mounting Western concern about developments in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: A passenger arrived at Donetsk airport on Tuesday as all flights in and out of eastern Ukraine were suspended.

item.title: In South Africa, A.N.C. Is Counting on the Past
item.description: The African National Congress, the party of Nelson Mandela, is poised to win the nation’s fifth democratic election, but it faces declining support among voters.
item.dc:creator: By NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:description: Residents of Gugulethu protested on Monday over housing and services. Some said they would not vote on Wednesday.

item.title: Obama Aides Tell Executives to Skip Forum
item.description: The White House has pressured the executives of some of America’s largest corporations into canceling plans to attend an economic forum in Russia to be hosted by President Vladimir V. Putin this month.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Beijing Kebab Vendors Among List of Polluters Hit With Fines
item.description: In the first four months of the year, the police in Beijing discovered 4,026 illegal cases of outdoor barbecuing and imposed fines totaling 21,900 renminbi, or more than $3,500, said an article about efforts to combat air pollution.
item.category: Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Kebab vendors checked their mobile phones as they waited for customers in an alley in Beijing.

item.title: India Ink: The Device that Runs the World’s Biggest Election
item.description: Thanks to a device that is the size and shape of a mini piano keyboard, India can boast that the country’s voters, all 814.5 million of them in 543 constituencies, can cast their ballot electronically.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: An electronic voting machine at a distribution center in Ghaziabad, Uttar Pradesh, on Apr. 9

item.title: Europe Expects Its Economy to Grow 1.6% This Year
item.description: The European Commission said growth across the 28-member European Union should reach 2 percent next year, compared with just 0.1 percent last year.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: “The recovery has now taken hold,” said Siim Kallas, vice president of the European Commission, during a press conference in Brussels.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: U.S. Air Force Aids Rescue of Chinese Fishermen in Pacific
item.description: Members of an Air Force rescue group parachuted into the Pacific Ocean off the Mexican coast to come to the aid of Chinese fishermen who had been forced to abandon their ship after it caught fire.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Staff Sgt. Adam Grant/United States Air Force, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An Air Force rescue team in a small craft approaching a Venezuelan fishing boat on Saturday after parachuting into the Pacific Ocean to help two injured Chinese on board.

item.title: World Briefing: Greece: 22 Migrants Die at Sea
item.description: A yacht and a dinghy crammed with immigrants trying to sneak into Greece capsized Monday, leaving at least 22 dead and several more missing in one of the deadliest accidents in Greek waters in recent years.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Haiti: Minimum Wage Increases
item.description: Haiti has slightly raised its minimum wage for the estimated 29,000 workers who sew T-shirts and other clothing in the country’s apparel factories.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Vietnam: Tensions Rise Over China’s Oil Rig
item.description: Vietnam demanded on Monday that China stop oil drilling operations in a disputed patch of the South China Sea.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Yemen: Gunmen Kill French Security Officer
item.description: France condemned an attack on the European Union’s security team in Yemen on Monday that left one Frenchman dead and two others wounded.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: World Briefing: Congo: Verdicts in Mass Rapes
item.description: A military court in the Democratic Republic of Congo has sentenced two soldiers to life in prison in connection with a mass rape in 2012.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: South Korea: Ferry Diver Dies
item.description: One of the civilian divers searching for victims of the South Korean ferry disaster died on Tuesday after losing consciousness underwater, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: India Ink: India Election Digest: May 6
item.description: A roundup of local election-related news for Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: Rahul Gandhi, vice president of the Indian National Congress party and its candidate for prime minister, addressing a rally in Allahabad, in the northern state of Uttar Pradesh, on Monday.

item.title: Beijing Steps Up Campaign Against Pollution
item.description: The city announced that it had imposed fines of more than $1.7 million against companies and business ventures that violated air pollution standards in the first four months of 2014.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Memo From Istanbul: With Conspiracy-Minded Intrigue, Life Imitates Fiction in Turkey
item.description: The country has seen an investigation involving top officials, accusations that foreigners are behind the inquiry, and a public feud between politicians and a preacher.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A scene from “Kizilelma,” a show about Turkey’s intelligence agency, in which an American agent tries to kill the prime minister.

item.title: Ex-General Vows to End Brotherhood if Elected
item.description: Abdul Fattah el-Sisi, the former general who led the military takeover of Egypt, declared there would be no reconciliation with the Muslim Brotherhood if he wins next month’s presidential election.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Syrian Opposition Delegation Is Given Diplomatic Status
item.description: The Obama administration on Monday pledged to the group $27 million in nonlethal assistance.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
